job_title: Registered Nurse, Oncology in Rockford, IL
pros:
The patient's and reimbursement for certifications pertaining to field of practice.
The organization strives to recognize associates that are doing good work.
cons:
I worked for the cancer center for three years. A patient that was recieving chemotherapy for a year had a lapse in insurance due to the new year. The patient was understandably scared that the treatment would keep getting delayed and the cancer would grow. The patient also had to pay for rides to the cancer center and the nurse caring for the patient stated he could not recieve treatment that we were waiting on approval of insurance. I was in a leadership role and gave the permission to give the chemotherapy, advocating for the patient. At first they tried to make me resign, stating I did not have the authority to authorize the treatment. I was never told I did not have that authority as I had approved treatments in the past under my leadership role. Ultimately they separated employment with me and then denied my unemployment which has put a huge strain on my family. I had never had any previous discipline and begged to keep my job. The patient's insurance ended up approving the treatment the next day and I was still let go. 
This company does not care about their associates and will get rid of you for next to nothing.

review_title: They Don't Care About the Employees
pros: if you need a pay check and you can't get hired anywhere else. . .
cons: You were expected to be a working RN so whenever someone called in you had to work their shift, in addition to doing your own work. . . some of the nurses made more per hour than what I did. . . constantly short staffed and HR would not take any action to reprimand those who constantly called off or lied. . . they always took the employee side and not the management who had all of the documentation to back up the need for terminating the employee. . this in turn made us look like we weren't doing anything to our staff that were working and do the job they were paid to do. . .

job_title: Emergency Room RN in Rockford, IL
pros: I had such a negative experience, I cannot think of any pros.
cons: I personally had a terrible experience there as an ED RN. It was very cliquey, gossipy and a very negative culture. Bullying (such as rudeness, public chastising, eye rolling, gossiping right in front of new employees, etc) was tolerated and if you spoke up it only got worse.  I was afraid every ER was like that but luckily my next ER job was amazing, encouraging and I was promoted to preceptor and charge RN there so I realized it wasn't me, it was the culture of that ER.

review_title: The hospital isn’t what it used to be
pros: Many employees within the healthcare system are friendly & caring. I like the fact that the hospital has concierge services - you can get your car oil change or dry cleaning done while working. If you are able to not get health insurance through the hospital, they have amazing “Wrap Plan” option, which reimburses all of the copays including healthcare & dental.
cons:
The hospital has changed toward the worse since Dr. Gorski, our old CEO has retired. The administration, management & HR are the worst I have ever experienced throughout my 18 years of working there. If you have serious concerns regarding workplace harassment or bullying, they will not care or support your concerns; they will support the bullies & allow them to continue to work without any consequences. During the coronavirus pandemic, the new CEO has decided to take away everyone’s scheduled vacation time - no other hospitals in the area have done so. We were told by management we cannot refuse to care of coronavirus positive patients - there are many healthcare workers that have serious health issues - asthma, immunocompromised, battling cancers & going through chemo. Making them work with these patients could literally kill them. 
So management & this new administration are treating all of their workers without any regard or sympathy toward them. It’s never been this bad as it is right now.
Also, the benefits are awful. We don’t have separate sick & vacation time; we accumulate very few vacation/sick time hours every 2 weeks. If you are pregnant, you have to use 2 weeks of your accrued vacation time & then if you qualify for short term disability, you only get paid 60% of your salary for only 4 weeks despite, for example, if you have C-section & according to doctor’s orders cannot return to work for 8 weeks - they will still only pay for 4 weeks. If you have surgery & need to be off work, you have to use all of your vacation hours - there isn’t an option to not use vacation hours if you don’t want to. And health insurance is really bad - luckily I am able to get it through my husband’s work. 
One more con - many units within the hospital are old & outdated; many work areas are unsafe & hazardous to work in. Most inpatient rooms are not private & very small. The hospital decided to invest lots of money into building many new clinics while ignoring the extremely outdated patient floors, ER, procedural areas.

pros: I greatly enjoyed the friendship that grew among my co-workers. We worked as a team and I always knew someone was there to help if I needed it. I also liked being a part of a nursing committee and having my voice heard regarding possible changes on the unit.
